summary:
Windows XP will soon be dead. The old OS should at least go on a well deserved rest, but some small niches still tie it to working life...

Many schools have all their computers still running under Windows XP. As they don’t have enough money to change all their computers, they are forced to survive with the old Windows Xp running on computers scavenged from companies garbages.

A few months ago, while reading some tweets about Raspberry PI, I had a disruptive idea : to replace all the old and sick computers on my childrens school with Raspberry PIs.

This talk is the tale of the construction of a system to replace all the old computers before septembre 2014. A system based on an customized Edubuntu as server, including internet content filter for children, network and account management, and Raspberry PIs as thin clients,  because vendor solution are too expensive and not fun, and I’m definitely a geek.
title: Raspberry PI-ing my school

summary:
Reactive and asynchronous programming is the latest hype for web development.  Why block a thread on a database query when the CPU could be looking at the next one?   While Asynchronous programming can help improve total throughput on a mult-core machine, the current state of the art lacks common patterns for how to define an asynchronous flow.

That’s all changed with JEP 155 and the new CompletableFuture in JDK8. 

This talk covers the new patterns in asynchronous programming, from joining together a series of asynchronous operations to chaining a pipeline of asynchronous tasks.  We’ll present a few core abstractions from functional programming that help define asynchronous workflow.
title: Reactive Programming Patterns with Java 8 Futures

summary: It is the corner cases of Android development that can be challenging even for the most experienced programmer. In this interactive session we will present 5 Android puzzles that dive deep into the framework and APIs, providing solutions to real world programming problems that will help you master your next Android project.
title: Riddle me this, Android Puzzlers

summary: The Scala BoF is a space to meet and greet other Scala developers, to learn from each other in an informal chat and to present your Scala project (framework, experiments, application).

summary:

Topics covered will include:

- Implicit conversions (now part of the advanced language features)

- Implicit AnyVals (blacker than the new black)
- Implicit Parameters for Configuration Passing
- Implicit Type Classes

Join us for a deep dive and learn how implicits are your friend, and not the enemy you thought they were.
title: Scala Implicits, the Real Story

summary: Writing secure software is better than plugging holes. A high level of automation is essential for building security into your software development lifecycle. David Tillemans, application security expert at Smals (www.smals.be), will talk about some standard security checks and demonstrate the essential testing tools. Findbugs and PMD are well know open source tools offering great security oriented features. ZAProxy, a web application security scanner developed by OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project), is great for testing the security issues of the  web frontend. It can be integrated in your test driven development lifecycle.  The session will demonstrate the integration of ZAproxy into Maven using a plugin and how to perform automatic web security scans based on your Selenium tests.

summary:
Selendroid is an open source test automation framework which drives of the UI of Android native and hybrid applications (apps). Tests are written using the Selenium 2 client API and for testing the application under test must not be modified.
This presentation demonstrates to the audience the challenges we face at eBay europe about mobile test automation of our Android apps. It shows based on real examples about how selendroid can be used to test native and hybrid Android apps, how the Selenium Grid can be used for parallel testing on multiple devices (emulators and hardware devices) and how cross platform test (between Android, web and iOS) can be written.
title: Selendroid - Selenium for Android Apps

summary: Shaping the future of web development, Google keynote on Thursday morning.
title: Shaping the future of web development

summary:
Recommendation engines are generally built such that a single kind of user interaction with a single kind of item is used to suggest the same kind of interaction with the same kind of item. In practice however, this approach is flawed for several reasons. First, multiple kinds of interactions with multiple kinds of items are typically available and should be used. Second, recommendation is better viewed as a ranking problem rather than a regression problem. Finally, practical recommendation systems should be constantly self-training as today’s recommendations and selections can be used to train tomorrow’s recommender.

This session will describe a practical recommendation architecture and implementation style that addresses all of the above issues and which is considerably easier to implement and deploy than conventional approaches. Several of the techniques that I will describe have never (to my knowledge) appeared in the research literature.
title: Simple Deployment of Recommendation Engines

summary:
Knockout.js provides a simplistic library for binding events to your HTML5 application.   When combined with Play frameworks simple websocket and Server-Sent-Event support, the combination becomes very powerful.

This talk will cover the basics of using Knockout.js with a focus on reacting to events sent over a stream from the web server.  We'll be building a Tic-Tac-Toe game, covering the fundamentals of:

* Basic template design with Knockout
* Mapping data from the server into observables
* Responding to Ui events
* Handling an event stream
title: Single Page Apps with Knockout.js and Play Framework

summary:
Spring Framework 4.0 is the next generation of the popular open source framework for Enterprise Java developers, focusing on the future with support for Java SE 8 & Java EE 7. In this presentation core Spring committer Sam Brannen will provide attendees an overview of the new enterprise features in the framework as well as new programming models made possible with the adoption of JDK 8 language features & APIs.

Specifically, this talk will cover support for lambda expressions & method references against Spring callback interfaces, JSR-310 Date-Time value types for Spring data binding & formatting, Spring's new @Conditional mechanism for activation of bean definitions, & a new WebSocket endpoint model. Regarding enterprise APIs, the presentation covers Spring 4.0's new support for JMS 2.0, JPA 2.1, Bean Validation 1.1, Servlet 3.1, JCache, & JSR-236 concurrency. Last but not least, Sam will discuss improvements to Spring's testing support & point out deprecations in the framework.
title: Spring Framework 4.0 - The Next Generation

summary: Every good webapp needs a UI and while your business users are painful, they still want to control the look and feel of any customer facing system.  Learn how to use dotcms (a Java Content Management System) to deploy content managed Spring web apps on running websites via osgi.  dotcms provides developers a way to hot swap classes and Spring controllers, to integrate content and even to push publish complete web apps between separate CMS instances or installations.
title: Spring Webapps + OSGi + dotcms = profit!

summary: Drones with attached sensors are the high-tech eyes of a modern farmer. Flying above the crop, they measure stress and growth. Tractors have become precision instruments and require detailed growth maps to be optimally utilized. How to put all this high tech to good use? Java plays a key role in connecting all these devices and furnishing sensible information to farmers. This session provides insight into how Java is used to evolve tech toys into precision agriculture instruments.

summary: Functional Web Testing - everyone wants it, (almost) everyone struggles with it. In this talk, we will demonstrate how to tame the beast with Spock and Geb, two popular testing tools from the Groovy/Java world. The goal is to arrive at readable, executable and maintainable specifications that still make sense the day after they have been written. Join in and judge for yourself!

summary: In the UK the school education system is experiencing radical reform. This is particularly the case with computing. There’s momentum to separate ICT from Computer Science and to place specific emphasis on the teaching of Computational Thinking. In broad terms, we shouldn’t just be teaching our children office skills such as formatting Word documents – we should be teaching them how to code and create their own software. This talk introduces Sonic Pi, a music language and environment running on the Raspberry Pi specifically focussed on introducing core Computer Science concepts within schools. Sonic Pi emphasises the importance of creativity in pedagogic contexts enabling learners to exhibit self-agency through the application of the taught ideas in musical works they create and own.
title: Teaching Computer Science with Music

summary: Thalmic Labs is the company behind Myo, the wearable gesture control armband that senses the movements of the muscles of the forearm to control digital devices.  We will be talking about the development of the Myo API. From it's inspirations, origin's and creation to how we have used it and our thoughts on where it can be taken.
title: Thalmic Labs - Myo API from init to flush

summary:
Enterprise Java developers value reliability and stability, but what happens to your technology stack if you’re willing to take a risk?  At jClarity we’re running production systems using Html 5, Angular.js, vertx, Mongo, groovy and deploying using chef.  Its been an interesting ride: some things worked really well and some things don’t.

Come along and find out what we’d recommend and what we’d avoid with hindsight.  We’ll also talk about how we ended up with such a diverse stack and how to make technology choices in a fairer way.  We’ve made the mistakes so you don’t have to.
title: The Bleeding Edge

summary: In this session you will learn the behind-the-scenes secrets of the Raspberry Pi powered Chess Demo.  This includes insight into how the chess pieces were moulded and the active chess board was fabricated, hardware design of the robotic arm including challenges with accuracy and calibration, and the state-of-the art in Java SE and Java ME embedded implementations.

summary:
As technology enthusiast we have often dreamt about having a flying robot to program and experiment with. The Crazyflie Nano Quadcopter is our attempt to make this dream a reality.
The development we started back in 2009 eventually lead to a open source palm­sized quadcopter development platform. The platform gives enthusiasts and developers a flying base on which to experiment on, hack or just fly for fun.
After years of late night development during our spare time we are really excited to see users flying the Crazyflie all over the world. Thanks to an active community worldwide we have gotten to see our quadcopter do things that we could never have done, or even imagined when we started out.
We will present part of our development journey, explain some of the technology behind our quadcopter and what the biggest challenges were. We will also show you some of the hacks and projects that we and the community have done over the years as well as give a flight demo.
title: The Crazyflie Nano Quadcopter development platform

summary: Implementing a programming language atop of Java platform brings up some curious integration challenges with it. In the process of designing Nashorn’s Java platform integration features, we had to figure out lots of things: How can you subclass Java classes in script? What interfaces should script objects expose to Java: map, list, both, none? What consequences do the different decisions bring? How to reconcile differences in array representation? What’s a correct JSON representation of a POJO? Should Java packages exist as objects? How much plumbing should we hide as a convenience to developers, and what should remain exposed lest they stumble across it in the dark? How does Java security model affect the design? We'll answer all these questions in this presentation.
title: The Curious Case of JavaScript on the JVM

summary:
Continuously testing your applications is important to maintain the quality and to make sure problems don’t occur after making changes to the applications. 
There are various frameworks out in the open that can help you create functional tests for your mobile applications. With many of these frameworks you need to have technical knowledge to create your functional tests. 
An exception to this rule is Calabash. This framework allows both technical and a-technical people to elegantly create functional tests for Android and iOS using natural language. Ali will be talking about Calabash and how easy it will become to create functional tests once entering the world of Calabash.
title: The elegance of functional testing using Calabash

summary:
Come and talk with the actors of the Groovy ecosystem: language implementors, framework authors, etc.

We'll talk about all things Groovy, what's in store for Groovy, Grails, Gradle, etc.

And we'll be happy to discuss with you and gather your feedback of where you'd love those project to be heading.
title: The Groovy ecosystem BOF

summary:
Most software development teams deliver applications over time, over budget and with a distinct lack of quality. However, some organisations and teams are orders of magnitude better, allowing their business to scale and be flexible in a rapidly changing world.

So how do you transform your organisation and teams from a cost center into part of your revenue generating business? How do you get your IT and software development teams to work at their creative best? How do you create those magic "x10" teams that the tech media keeps talking about?

Over the past 12 years Martijn Verburg (aka The Diabolical Developer) has specialised in transforming technical teams. From deep tech start-ups through to ponderous government departments, he'll cover the cultural and technical habits of the highly effective teams.

He's going to unveil the truth, and also tell you what not to do from bitter first, second and third hand experience.
title: The Habits of Highly Effective Technical Teams

summary:
I think most of us will agree that modularity is a Good Thing. However, while it is possible to create nice modular applications, current languages do not offer a lot of tools that would make this task easier. Hence we'll start by creating a (subjective) list of requirements for an "ideal" module system, just to know how much more work is needed.

Then we will take a look at Java packages. We usually think about packages in a hierarchical way, yet they are treated by tools as simple identifiers. We use them for scoping, but Java only supports package-private scope. We could use them as a module system, but we create build modules instead.

I'd like to show two approaches to solving this problem. One is Veripacks, a Java/Scala library which verifies transitive module-related annotations. Second is the module system in Ceylon, where modularity is one of the main features of the language. I'll also compare with OSGi, and show how it differs.
title: The ideal module system and the harsh reality

summary:
You are developing Java applications for years now, and you are used to have a very complete and powerful software factory: Git(Hub), Jenkins, Sonar, you practice TDD, BDD, etc..
But now your JavaScript codebase grows constantly, and you are wondering how to make your developments faster, safer, stronger, with a good software factory and well-chosen tools dedicated to JavaScript.
So, how to industrialize your JavaScript developments?

During this Quickie, we will make a tour of all the important components for your Software Factory, explaining how you can reuse your current tools, and also by introducing new elements such as Yeoman.
title: The ingredients for a perfect JavaScript Software Factory

summary: The applications technology landscape surrounding the Internet of Things (IoT), also called machine-to-machine (M2M) communications, is a Wild West environment full of proprietary technology implementations and a highly fragmented vendor ecosystem. To address the ever-growing IoT environment, Java offers developers a standards-based platform to enable highly integrated end-to-end solutions. This session outlines some of the key issues developers face today in developing, scaling, and extending end-to-end M2M solutions. With the help of sample reference use cases, attendees will learn of the benefits of using Java Embedded to address both the challenges and opportunities in IoT.
title: The Internet of Things with Java

summary:
HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, jQuery, Angular JS, Bootstrap, Mobile, CoffeeScript, GitHub, functional programming, Page Speed, Apache, JSON with Jackson, caching, REST, Security, load testing, profiling, Wro4j, Heroku, Cloudbees, AWS. 

These are just some of the buzzwords that a Java web developer hears on a daily basis. This talk is designed to expose you to a plethora of technologies that you might've heard about, but haven't learned yet. We'll concentrate on the most important web developer skills, as well as UI tips and tricks to make you a better front-end engineer. Some of the most valuable engineers these days have front-end JS/CSS skills, as well as backend Java skills.
title: The Modern Java Web Developer

summary: Project Jigsaw aims to create a simple, friendly, and scalable standard module system for the Java platform. This session explains its key goals and design principles, shows the progress made in the past year, and demonstrates its use.
title: The Modular Java Platform and Project Jigsaw

summary: In this Quickie an example will be shown about how to use JavaScript to script a JavaFX application on the Raspberry Pi by using Nashorn which is the new JavaScript runtime engine that will come with JDK8. When developing for the Raspberry Pi you most of the times code on your desktop, create an executable jar file, copy it to the Pi and start it there. In the case of modification you have to modify the code on the desktop, create the jar and copy it to the Pi again. To improve this workflow Nashorn comes in very handy because it let you script your application during runtime by executing JavaScript files.
title: The Nashorn, the Pi and some JavaFX

summary: Spring 4.0 is upon us, along with Spring XD, a whole slew of new Java configuration-powered APIs, a Batch JSR implementation, incredible improvements in the Spring Data space, along with the most complete support for REST in the industry. A lot has happened or emerged in the last year in the Spring world. Let's talk about it - bring your questions and let's look at where Spring is, and where it's going, together.
title: The Spring BOF

summary:
Kotlin is a statically-typed JVM-targeted programming language developed by JetBrains. One of its major goals is to provide developers with safer and more concise language than Java while keeping simple enough for industrial use.

So far, so good. But can we somehow assess these qualities?    

Famous "Java Puzzlers" series of talks (as well as the book) made it clear that there are quite a few cases when Java programs display counterintuitive or just obscure behavior. While some are JVM-related, most of those cases have roots in Java language design. Now, we tried to translate the puzzlers to Kotlin and compare them with the originals.

In this talk we're going to tell the story of Java puzzlers from the Kotlin perspective which would demonstrate how Kotlin design helps to eliminate some problematic issues found in Java. In particular, we'd consider such aspects as expressions and control structures, exception handling, object and classes, nullable types and extentions.
title: The Unpuzzling Kotlin: Bringing Clarity to Your Code

summary:
Functional Programming has been around for a while, but it is gaining popularity, especially due to direct support in languages on the JVM. Writing code in functional style is not about syntax. It is a paradigm shift. In this presentation, using examples from Java, Groovy, and Scala, you will learn how to write code in functional style. We will start out discussing the elements of functional programming and then look at examples of some common operations and how you can implement those in functional style.

Then we will explore the functional style of programming in Groovy.  Groovy is not a functional programming language, writing in functional style is common and idiomatic in Groovy. While you have used these features in Groovy, learning the tenets of functional programming will help you recognize these and make better use of them in the future.
title: Thinking Functional Style

summary:
The Play! framework makes web development a pleasure by providing type-safe ways of building applications, catching many possible mistakes upfront at compilation time rather than at runtime.

As a Play application grows in size, however, the configuration for building and structuring a project may require some tuning in order to keep the development lifecycle fast and productive.

Additionally there is a number of tools and libraries that can support individual developers and teams to stay productive: code formatting with scalariform, style checking with scalastyle, front-end testing Selenium and Chrome (also on Jenkins), BDD with Cucumber, etc.

This quickie will quickly go over a number of these techniques and tools, and pragmatically show how to configure them.
title: Tips and tricks for setting up a Play 2 project

summary:
"Do the maximum, not matter what it costs or how long it takes" -
that's what we never hear. UI engineering enables us to reach the best possible UI under given constraints.
Every application is only as good as its weakest link. But while much thought and effort is spent to engineer the backend, the frontend is generally judged only by the visual appearance without paying much attention to solid and sustainable internals.
We will go through the fallacies that lead to this situation, explain why this is inefficient, suggest improvements, and picture a better future. 
All this comes with practical examples, anecdotes from the field, and considerations about design, usability, and the constraints under which UIs are developed.
We will end with a call to action where UI engineers shall form a community to advance their profession.
Everybody who is remotely interested in user interfaces, usability, and first-class applications will enjoy the show.
title: UI Engineer - the missing profession

summary:
Karma (formerly known as Testacular) is a test runner that makes unit testing of client-side code fun!

Designed from ground up with the best possible workflow in mind, Karma is now one of the most popular test runners out there and has become the testing tool of choice for the AngularJS community and beyond.

http://karma-runner.github.io/
title: Unit testing JavaScript/CoffeeScript/Dart code with Karma

summary: Today we are in the age of apps, for almost every platform there exists an app-store. Users are 1 click away from millions of applications, this means that your app has 1 chance in a million to get selected. So when your app got noticed and installed by somebody you have very little time to convince them they installed the right app. The user-experience and usability of the app is therefore very crucial. Today's analytics tools can be used to understand how people use the application but it doesn't tell you anything why users are doing it that way! Techniques and methods from the User-Experience domain should be combined with this analytics data to better understand it. During this session we'll show participants how they could use an online service like UXprobe to combine analytics with surveys and likability feedback to improve the apps they build.
title: User-Experience Metrics for Apps

summary: This session will demonstrate how to build and deploy Java ME embedded applications using the Java ME SDK. Will demonstrate on device deployment, profiling and debugging of application using a ARM based Keil evaluation board mcbstm32f200, Raspberry Pi and the built in ME SDK device emulator.
title: Using the Java ME SDK to build real world embedded applications

summary: This introduction to WebJars will explain the reasons for managing JavaScript and CSS assets like traditional dependencies.  Attendees will learn how to get started using WebJars and integrate them with RequireJS.
title: WebJars - The Web in JARs

summary:
Look behind the scenes of what we are thinking about for the next big version of Angular. Here are some hints:  Hierarchical injection; Async injectors; Object.observe(); Hybrid world through web-components  (all frameworks play nice together);  JavaScript annotations;
 Better Directive API (composition of directives); How do things work: DI, Dirty Checking, Compiler
title: What is in store for the future of Angular

summary:
While the Java EE spec is quite modular, the current implementation (JBoss AS, Spring, Glassfish, etc) of the spec are quite monolithic and it's not that easy to compose parts of one implementations with parts of another one.

I will present how most popular Java EE implementation works under the hood, what are the Java techniques and tricks used by those implementations and how this can be abstracted to a set of common operations.

Then I will explain how the tools used by the dynamic language runtimes written on top of the JVM introduced in Java 7 can be re-purposed to be used to implement the backbone of any Java EE implementation in order to make it each of its parts composable.
title: What Java EE can learn from dynamic languages?

summary:
Groovy is not a newcommer in the arena of alternative languages for the JVM.
But with over 1.7 million downloads a year, it's clearly ahead of the pack.

And what makes it a great choice for your projects?
- a flat learning curve for Java developers
- its seemless Java integration where you can mix & mash Groovy & Java together
- a maleable & concise syntax fit for Domain-Specific Languages
- an interesting take on type safety
- its rich ecosystem of projects: Grails, Gradle, GPars, Spock, Griffon, Geb...

In this session, we'll see how this all fits together in the big Groovy picture, when and where you can use Groovy, and how you can take advantage of Groovy for boosting your productivity!
title: What Makes Groovy Groovy

summary: Engineers from the Android team at Google will give at overview of the latest developer features of the Android platform.
title: What's New in Android

summary: JavaFX 8 contains many new and exciting features for JavaFX developers, including enhancements to WebView’s HTML5 support , 3-D, the ability to embed Swing nodes inside a JavaFX Scene Graph, new UI controls, a new visual theme, and much more. JavaFX has also been ported to a variety of new embedded platforms. In this session an overview of the new functionality in JavaFX 8 and OpenJFX will be given, and JavaFX 8 development, including Lambda features, will be demonstrated on a Raspberry Pi.
title: What's New in JavaFX 8

summary: Explore your new choices in working with Java and Windows. Here a personal account of how Microsoft is working with friends including Oracle, Azul System and the Eclipse community, to realize rainbows and unicorns in white clouds with Java. You’re also invited to join the bliss with simple tips and tricks to work with Java and Windows. The cloud continues to bring change with an increasing demand to make the mixed up world of IT work better together. The old black or white debate around open source software is simply no longer relevant. Open cloud platforms and a demand for cross-platform developer tools have created new industry alliances. Come see the unicorn!
title: White clouds, rainbows and unicorns: Java and Windows

summary:
JBoss AS is now called WildFly and it is even faster!

Come to discuss (over beer) the present and future of the WildFly community project with distinguished members of the JBoss Core Development Team!
title: WildFly Application Server - Community BOF

summary:
Xtend is a flexible and expressive dialect of Java. It compiles to idiomatic source code that can be compiled and run an any JVM since Java5. Without any gap, you can use all you favorite Java libraries. The compiled Java source code is readable and pretty printed, runs as fast as handwritten code and can be processed by existing tools like annotation processors or static code analyzers.

If you want to become more productive and write beautiful code with powerful macros, lambdas, and many more modern language features, Xtend is the right choice. In this code centric session, you'll see it in action with real world examples using JavaFX, Android and other exciting frameworks.
title: Xtend in Action

summary: Are you an impatient programmer who wishes the keyboard could keep up with you? If you've ever wished Java and Spring could do more to keep up, then this is the place to be. We present Spring Boot, a toolkit and runtime platform that will get you up and running with Spring-powered, production-grade applications and services faster than you believed possible. We will start the training with a few basics about Spring depending on audience experience and then move into sharing the goals of Spring Boot.
title: Zero Effort Spring
